item.text: Alan Turing introduced this test of AI in his 1950 paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence" This begins with the words: "I propose to consider the question, 'Can machines think?'"

Alan Turing introduced this test of AI in his 1950 paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence". [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html html] This begins with the words: "I propose to consider the question, 'Can machines think?'"
He suggested that if a computer could pass his interrogation game
He suggested that if a computer could pass his imitation game
He suggested an imitation game as a test.
quote

It is played with three people, a man (A), a woman (B), and an interrogator (C) who may be of either sex. The interrogator stays in a room apart front the other two. The object of the game for the interrogator is to determine which of the other two is the man and which is the woman. He knows them by labels X and Y, and at the end of the game he says either "X is A and Y is B" or "X is B and Y is A."

It is played with three people, a man (A), a woman (B), and an interrogator (C) who may be of either sex. The interrogator stays in a room apart front the other two. The object of the game for the interrogator is to determine which of the other two is the man and which is the woman. He knows them by labels X and Y, and at the end of the game he says either "X is A and Y is B" or "X is B and Y is A." [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html html]
end quote

We now ask the question, "What will happen when a machine takes the part of A in this game?" Will the interrogator decide wrongly as often when the game is played like this as he does when the game is played between a man and a woman? These questions replace our original, "Can machines think?"

It is played with three people, a man (A), a woman (B), and an interrogator (C) who may be of either sex. The interrogator stays in a room apart front the other two. The object of the game for the interrogator is to determine which of the other two is the man and which is the woman. He knows them by labels X and Y, and at the end of the game he says either "X is A and Y is B" or "X is B and Y is A."

We now ask the question, "What will happen when a machine takes the part of A in this game?" Will the interrogator decide wrongly as often when the game is played like this as he does when the game is played between a man and a woman? These questions replace our original, "Can machines think?" [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html html]

"I propose to consider the question, 'Can machines think?'" is how [[Alan Turing]] introduced his seminal 1950 paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence" in which he outlined the basis for an experiment that could test for the presence of the ability to think or intelligence - [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html loebner.net]

These questions replace our original, "Can machines think?" [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html loebner.net]

<H3>The Imitation Game

"I propose to consider the question, 'Can machines think?'" is how [[Alan Turing]] introduced his 1950 paper [[Computing Machinery and Intelligence]].
The name he himself gave to what we now call the [[Turing Test]], was the "imitation game".

story.text: [[Alan Turing]] first proposed an "imitation game' as a way to test an entity for the presence of the ability to think - that is intelligence.
The Loebner Prize is an annual competition that puts the [[Turing Test]] into practice, held since 1990 - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loebner_Prize wikipedia]
The name he himself gave to what we now call the [[Turing Test]], was the "imitation game".
[[Alan Turing]] proposed this [[Thought Experiment]] in his seminal 1950 paper [[Computing Machinery and Intelligence]] - [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html loebner.net]

It is played with three people, a man (A), a woman (B), and an interrogator (C) who may be of either sex. The interrogator stays in a room apart front the other two. The object of the game for the interrogator is to determine which of the other two is the man and which is the woman. He knows them by labels X and Y, and at the end of the game he says either "X is A and Y is B" or "X is B and Y is A."

We now ask the question, "What will happen when a machine takes the part of A in this game?" Will the interrogator decide wrongly as often when the game is played like this as he does when the game is played between a man and a woman? These questions replace our original, "Can machines think?" - [http://www.loebner.net/Prizef/TuringArticle.html loebner.net]

Sometimes people have difficulty believing that machines cannot think. Douglas Hofstadter talks about [[ELIZA]], and related issues, his book in Godel, Escher, Bach. [http://www.physixfan.com/wp-content/files/GEBen.pdf pdf]
John Searle uses his [[Chinese Room]] thought experiment to criticise this in his 1980 paper Minds, Brains and Programs - [http://cogprints.org/7150/1/10.1.1.83.5248.pdf cogprints.org]
